awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Transformative Approaches for Hardware Obfuscation Protection, Attacks, and Assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
Electronic computing hardware forms the foundation of modern information systems and cyber infrastructure. However, the unavoidable involvement of untrusted parties  who can insert malicious circuits (i.e., hardware Trojans), steal intellectual property (IP), and produce counterfeits have made hardware more vulnerable to cyber-attacks. National defense, welfare, and economic growth all suffer through 1) weaker security and quality of critical infrastructures; 2) substantial economic and reputational losses for IP owners; 3) increased revenue for terrorist groups, criminals, and adversarial nation states; and 4) lower incentive to innovate and develop new products. The objective of this project is to advance the state-of-the-art in hardware obfuscation for IP protection. Hardware obfuscation refers to transformation of a circuit design into one that is functionally equivalent to the original, but infeasible to reverse engineer and/or obtain unrestricted use without significant effort. 

This project targets four major limitations associated with existing hardware obfuscation techniques: 1) Impractical overheads for real-world designs; 2) Susceptibility to attacks; 3) Poor scalability to large circuits of practical interest; and 4) lack of metrics and benchmarks in the research community to objectively compare different methods. Efficiency and scalability are being improved by developing novel circuit entropy metrics and holistic obfuscation algorithms that operate on decision diagrams. Outreach activities dedicated to obfuscation and awareness of IP piracy issues include creation of the first publically available benchmarks, conducting online global competitions, and generating new course materials, projects, and book. Through integration of these activities, measureable improvements in the attack resistance of obfuscated combinational and sequential designs are expected by project's end.

por.por_cntn:
The outsourcing of critical steps of the hardware design/fabrication process has rendered electronic systems more vulnerable. Most notably, untrusted parties involved in the integrated circuit (IC) design/fabrication flow can insert malicious circuits (i.e., hardware Trojans), steal intellectual property (IP), and produce counterfeits. Hardware Trojans can be well-hidden "time bombs" that cause hardware failure at critical moments or backdoors that intentionally leak sensitive information. In the context of hardware, IP refers to a reusable unit of logic, cell, or chip layout design that is either licensed to another party or owned and used solely by a single party. Counterfeit ICs and malicious modifications can occur whenever IP is stolen. In parallel to such attacks, hardware implementations of electronic systems are increasingly vulnerable to non-invasive "side-channel" attacks where secret information from the system, including assets and IP, can be extracted. All these threats have nontrivial impacts on government, industry, and society including security and assurance risks for critical systems and infrastructures, loss of consumer privacy, substantial economic and reputational losses for IP owners, sources of revenue for terrorist groups and organized crime, and finally reduced incentive to develop new products, thereby impacting worldwide innovation, economic growth, and employment.

This project investigated obfuscation to mitigate these threats. Obfuscation is generally defined as "the obscuring of the intended meaning of communication by making the message difficult to understand". In the context of hardware and software, obfuscation refers to transformation of a design or program into one that is functionally equivalent to the original, but infeasible to reverse engineer using a reasonable amount of effort. Hardware obfuscation can be applied at various steps of the design/fab flow to "lock" an IP module, thereby protecting it from threats by untrusted parties further down the line (e.g., protect 3PIP providers from IC designers, IC designers from untrusted fabs, and so on). The IP can later be "unlocked" by a trusted party to achieve its original function. In doing so, the IP is more difficult to use and/or to modify by unauthorized parties. Further, obfuscation can be used to hide side-channel (timing, power, etc.) leakage and thereby protect hardware and software assets from theft.

The major outcomes of this project can be summarized as follows:

  • Novel obfuscation approaches were developed, including CASLock and covert gates. The former approach was the first logic locking scheme capable of overcoming the tradeoff between the state-of-the-art SAT attack and output corruptibility. Covert gates represented an innovative improvement over existing IC camouflaging techniques because they were visually indistinguishable from standard logic gates. Even under pessimistic assumptions where the attacker has considerable information on the types of gates being camouflaged, indistinguishability made SAT and test-based attacks against covert gates infeasible. In the final year of the project, a promising new mimicking/deception application of covert gates and camouflaging was proposed to intentionally misdirect reverse engineers.
  • Multiple new machine learning (ML) attacks against hardware obfuscation were developed and verified. First, key sweeping could identify the locking keys from locked combinational circuits with greater than 75% accuracy and 94% precision in a matter of seconds. Second, state-of-the-art analog IC locking techniques were proven useless after being broken using evolutionary algorithms in mere minutes. Attacks against obfuscated sequential circuits were also investigated and significant weaknesses were identified.
  • This project resolved barriers comparing different obfuscation schemes as well as attacks against them. Namely, existing benchmark circuits were not designed to examine obfuscation, are small, and are too few in number. Thus, they cannot be used to demonstrate scalability or to support data-driven approaches that require large volumes of data (e.g., deep learning). This project produced synthetic benchmark generation tools capable of creating arbitrary numbers of benchmarks with desired number of inputs, outputs, and logic elements, degree of structural diversity, and logic function. Different hardware Trojan detection and obfuscation schemes were tested on these benchmarks to examine their effectiveness, scalability, and overhead. Further, the tools were made open source for the community.
  • The first hardware de-obfuscation competition was organized by the PI. Excluding the PI's blue team, the competition involved 9 red teams in total (6 domestic and 3 international). Results of the competition were presented by the PI and the winning team (Auburn University) at the Trusted and Assured MicroElectronics (TAME) Forum. Travel for finalists was paid for and the winners received a monetary prize using industry sponsorship.

The outcomes of this project have led to deeper understanding of the benefits and limitations of IP protection through obfuscation. Ultimately, this should benefit (i) military, defense, and the US government organizations who need to safeguard their IPs related to national security; (ii) for-profit and non-profit organizations who seek to protect their revenue from IP licenses; and (iii) consumers by protecting their health and safety from inferior product quality associated with stolen/tampered IPs.
